awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Role of Advanced Simulation Technologies in Innovation Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This set of studies will examine the role of advanced, computer-based simulations in managerial and policy-making decisions by comparing the work of scientists, engineers, managers and policymakers in three different disciplines: automotive engineering, atmospheric research, and urban planning. Research suggests that if the outputs of computer simulations appear to have high visual fidelity with the physical systems they represent, lay users are likely to believe that simulations make accurate predictions. This project will examine the use of simulation-based evidence by both technical and non-technical users during the search, generation and persuasion phases of decisions. The project will employ ethnographic methods to identify and assess representations and understandings of simulation products, patterns in acceptance and use, and associated changes in organizations' formal and informal influence structures. 

The results from these studies will give managers and policy makers insight into the consequences that new simulation technologies have for decision-making and, by association, decision-related organizational structures. By improving our understanding of how simulation models become persuasive communication devices, the results of this study will also provide policymakers with the appropriate questions to ask to determine the assumptions underlying simulation models and will give them a more general understanding of when and how simulations can be misleading or helpful.

por.por_cntn:
As occurs with most new communication technologies, there is a great optimism that enterprise social networking tools will revolutionize the way that work takes place within contemporary organizations. In one of the most striking examples, the authors of recent report by the McKinsey Global Institute suggest that enterprise social networking site use in the workplace could result in up to $1.3 trillion of annual value across the financial services, consumer packaged goods, professional services, and advanced manufacturing sectors, and that knowledge workers in these sectors who use enterprise social networking tools for internal communication and collaboration have the potential to increase their productivity by more than 20%.

Taking a more measured and focused view, the goal of this study was to explore whether enterprise social networking tools can help improve one important organizational activity: internal knowledge sharing. Effective internal knowledge sharing is tremendously important for organizations. Organizations that are able to get quality knowledge to the right people at the right time tend to be more innovative, have more satisfied employees and are able to bring products and services to market faster than competitors. For these reasons, intraorganizational knowledge sharing and organizational learning are increasingly popular topics of study for organizational theorists at both micro and macro levels of analysis., Consequently, if enterprise social networking technologies can improve intraorganizational knowledge sharing, elucidating the mechanisms by which such improvement occurs will have important practical consequences for organizational managers and important theoretical consequences for organizational scientists. 

By focusing on three empirical studies in different large organizations, this study examined whether and how social tools could be used for knowledge sharing and innovaiton. 

Together these studies showed that social tools can help make everyday communication wtihin organizations visible to those who would not typically see it. Once invisible communication occurring between others in the organization becomes visible for third parties to see, those third parties may be able to improve their metaknowledge (knowledge of “who knows what” and “who knows whom” in the organization). Communication visibility leads to enhanced awareness of who knows what and whom through two interrelated mechanisms: message transparency and network translucence. Seeing the contents of other people’s messages helps third-party observers to make inferences about the knowledge other people have and seeing the structure of other people’s communication networks helps third-party observers to make inferences about who those people talk with on a somewhat regular basis. These findings further suggests that enhanced metaknowledge can lead to more innovative products and services and less knowledge duplication if individuals learn to work in new ways. Specifically, individuals will be able to recombine existing ideas into new ideas more effectively and avoid duplicating work that has already been done if they switch from learning through experience to learning vicariously and if they can begin to proactively aggregate information they are perceiving daily rather than engage in reactive search after they have run up against a problem they cannot solve.    

These findings have several important implications for the nature of work in the knowledge economy. One implication, shown clearly in the data presented above is that communication visibility and the improved metaknowledge it can enable bring the possibility of making work in organizations more streamlined and more innovative. By learning “who knows what” and “who knows whom” employees at American Financial were able to save themselves and the company time and money that would have otherwise been wasted on duplication of knowledge and work. Consequently, people who were best equipped to solve problems were doing so, which is, of course, the goal of work specialization and of encouraging intraorganizational collaboration (Ren & Argote, 2011). Also, employees were able to be more innovative in their work by recombining knowledge that already existed in the organization into new ideas for products and services. Burt (2004: 351) suggests that people who are adept at innovating through recombination of knowledge have a “vision advantage” that others in the organization do not. Burt suggests that this vision advantage comes from bridging across structural holes in an organization’s communication network. But the findings of this study suggest that through the use of technologies like enterprise social networking sites that makes communication among individuals visible to those not involved in it may provide all users of the technology with the vision advantage necessary to conduct successful recombinant innovation, regardless of network position.
